Comment: In France, the last libertarian party (which was called Démocratie Libérale) dissolved in 2002, and its founder Alain Madelin only got 4% of the vote at the presidential election of that time, so you can say it is extremely unpopular.   This doesn’t stop the French Left from always accusing their center-right opponents (such as Macron) of being libertarians (or neoliberals), even though Macron keeps intervening in the economy through subventions and regulations and is actually very Keynesianist (but less so than the French Left). It reminds me of the way the U.S. Republicans will always accuse the U.S. Democrats of being communists even when it makes absolutely no sense.

Author: Ashamed_Job_8151

Comment: In the UK Liz Truss became Prime Minister in September 2022 after a leadership contest in the Conservative party. On the 23rd of September 2022 her Chancellor introduced a 'mini-budget' including a large number cuts to income taxes and National Insurance and rollbacks of other planned tax increases, heavily influenced by free-market think tanks such as the IEA, for which she refused to have the Office for Budget Responsibility do the typical economic forecast for major legislation.  Economists panned it, the markets panicked, the pound dropped precipitously and kept dropping, mortgage products were being cancelled and it turned out that the Bank of England hadn't known about the budget beforehand which made matters worse when they raised interest rates. A week after the mini-budget large parts of it were rolled back, the Chancellor was fired, and despite struggling on Liz Truss resigned as Prime Minster three weeks later on the 20th of October.  That's the high point of libertarianism in the UK, I don't think even the Tories will be embracing anyone from that wing of the party for a long time to come.  https://www.newsweek.com/how-liz-truss-libertarian-experiment-crashed-burned-uk-1753884  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/September_2022_United_Kingdom_mini-budget#The_budget

Comment: >Humans are lazy and consequently are always looking for the "easy button" when it comes to problem solving.   That easy button can resemble technological advancements or plunder of another person's property.  I firmly believe that's capitalism's fault, not human nature.  We've bred humans to want to do the minimal work possible to achieve advanced wealth and then sit on it. In an ideal society, everyone works together as a community to provide needs to one another. True individualism breeds adversarialism and stifles compassion and empathy.   But we probably just fundamentally disagree on this, as I am a left libertarian/anarchocommunist, not a right one. I grew up as a right libertarian, though, and I both understand the mindset and even somewhat sympathize with it to some degree. My dad is still a right libertarian and we have a Venn diagram of things that we agree on in the middle that keep us having regular constructive conversations.
